text: back in 2003 the UK government carried
out a
survey and it was a survey that measured
levels of numeracy in the population and
they were shocked to find out that for
every 100 working age adults in the
country 47 of them lacked level one
numeracy skills now level one numeracy
skills that's low-end GCSE score it's
the ability to deal with fractions
percentages and decimals so this figure
prompted a lot of hand ringing in uh
White Hall policies were changed
Investments were made and then they ran
the survey again in 2011 so can you
guess what happened to this
number it went up to
49 and in fact when I reported this

joked and said this figure is only
shocking to 51% of the
population well I preferred uh actually
the reaction of a school child who said
to me when I presented to a school this
information said raise the hand and said
how do we know that the person who made
that number isn't one of the 49%
either so you know clearly there's a a

the changes that we want to introduce uh

so there's definitely um a numeracy

hering people in advertently into one of

comfortable with numbers that can do

suppose what I'm trying to talk about
here today is to say that I believe that
that is a false dichotomy it's not an

that that should be the starting point

what made me think that statistics was

the average answer from this survey
which was supposed to be representative
of the Border population was
24 that's what people thought British
people think 24 out of every 100 people
in the country a Muslim Now official

five so so there's this big variation
between what we think our perception and

and I think that's interesting what
could possibly be causing that

with this study I started to take

and they had every right to be angry
because in fact I'd have to have closer

nearer to
34s um so again a big big variation and
I love this one they they asked in Japan
they said uh they asked the Japanese for

again this is the average was about a

out of every 100 Japanese people lived

poor intuitive

how well do you know 64 million people
not very well it turns out you know I

do you know your
area it's a simple web app you put in a

in designing this that I wanted to make

um I was inspired by the isotypes of
uton Noir from the 1920s and 30s now
these are methods for representing uh
numbers using repeating icons and if you
like the numbers are there but they sit
in the background so it's a great way of
representing quantity without resorting

and ratio so here's the quiz the layout
of the quiz is you have your repeating
icons on the leftand side there and a
map showing you the area we're asking
you questions about on the right hand
side there are seven questions each
question there's a possible answer
between zero and 100 and at the end of
the quiz you get an overall score
between zero and 100 and so because this
is tedex exitor I thought we would have
a quick look at the quiz for the first
few questions of of exitor and so the
first question is for every 100 people
how many are aged under 16 now I don't

about the next question this is asking

um actually in exitor it's incredibly

and I hedged my bets here cuz I didn't

there are Clues to whether a

something like home ownership is much
more difficult to see and so we revert

we've had online applications that allow

their own

uh was more than I could have hoped for
it was a long-held ambition of mine to

public
demand uh this URL contains the word
